#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:47:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
3 hours of severe left sided chest pressure. Radiates to arm. Associated shortness of breath. Denies hx MI. Mildly
diaphoretic. Aspirin 324 per EMS.
HPI/PE:
Patient is a 68 y/o M w/ PMH HTN, HLD, CKD (not on dialysis) presenting for eval chest pain. Reports
chest pain started approximately 3 hours. Pressure-like, exertional Radiates to L shoulder. Does not
radiate to back. No ripping/tearing quality. Non-pleuritic. Associated with some SOB that worsens when
laying flat.
Denies prior hx ACS. Denies family hx early cardiovascular disease.
Does not see a cardiologist.
No hx DVT/PE. No hx recent surgery, immobilization, hormones. No smoking.
No fevers, chills, infectious symptoms.
MDM:
68M with risk factors and chest pain concerning for ACS. Initial troponin noted to be markedly elevated.
No history of prior troponin in chart. ECG no ST segment changes but some LVH. Cardiology consulted,
recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission. Low clinical suspicion for DVT/PE. No pneumonia/pnx
on CXR. Got aspirin pre-hospital. Heparin. Hold off on Brilinta per cardiology. Adm.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [06/29/23 1422]
BP: (!) 163/95
Pulse: (!) 115
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 22
Temp: 99.1 °F (37.3 °C)
Temp src: Oral
SpO2: 97%
BP (!) 163/95 | Pulse (!) 115 | Temp 99.1 °F (37.3 °C) (Oral) | Resp 22 | Wt (Wt Unknown)
Physical Exam
Procedures
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 06/29/23 1531
NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) (HC Code) (HC CODE) (HC Code)
ED Disposition
Admit

ENCOUNTER NOTE #2
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Registered Nurse


02:25 PM Pt w/ 3 hours chest pain, diaphoretic, uncomfortable appearing. NC O2 for comfort. Pt aox4,
vss. Steady gait. 8/10 chest pain. Radiates to shoulder. Aspirin by EMS. Tech getting EKG.
02:31 PM Medicated per MAR. MD at bedside, blood sent to lab.
03:15 PM Troponin 124. MD aware. Cardiology MD at bedside talking to pt.
03:38 PM Pt now admitted to telemetry unit. Pain better, now 2/10. Wife calling for update, explained
plan for adm, requesting update from MD.
05:31 PM Pt ambulatory with steady gait to bathroom.
06:32 PM Report given to tele floor RN. Transport booked.

Chief Complaint

• Flank Pain
2x days flank pain no vomiting no diarhea sometimes bloody urine never had kidney stones. No fevers/chills. Patient

Non-smoker. Has never seen a urologist, no prior cysto. Pain worse at night. Crampy, uncomfortable. Has trouble

No results found for this visit on 06/14/23.

Vitals and nursing note reviewed.
Constitutional:
Appearance: He is not in distress.
HENT:
Head: Normocephalic and atraumatic.
Eyes:
Conjunctiva/sclera: Conjunctivae normal.
Neck:
Trachea: No tracheal deviation.
Cardiovascular:

Flank pain
ED Clinical Impression(s)
The encounter diagnosis was Flank pain.
Plan
Given intermittent flank pain without clear laterality concern for possible renal vs MSK vs aortic
etiology. Low suspicion for aortic dissection. Doubt surgical emergency. Recommended renal
ultrasound to patient however ultrasound has already closed for the day. Patient does not want to
wait overnight for ultrasound to open in the morning. Would rather go home with close PMD follow-
up. Counseled on risks of leaving without definitive workup, after shared ecision making patient
understyands risk. Doubt life-threatening process. Counseled on return precautions.
ED Disposition
Discharge

ENCOUNTER NOTE #4
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-14 16:17:00
Type: ED Visit 
Provider: Registered Nurse


2:20 PM Patient arrives to ED for eval of flank pain x 2 days. Some blood in urine. No fevers, chills, chest
pain, shortness of breath. In no acute distress. Needs to get home soon to take care of grandkids.
2:43 PM MD at bedside. Plan of care explained to patient, will need ultrasounds.
2:45 PM Called ultrasound to schedule, closed for day. MD on phone with radiologist figuring out when
ultrasound can get done.
2:50 PM MD at bedside explaining ultrasound can’t be done until 9am tomorrow because lab is down.
3:34 PM MD at bedside discharging patient. VSS, ambulatory with steady gait. Patient verbalized
understanding and acceptance of discharge instructions. Discharged to home. All belongings returned to
patient.

ENCOUNTER NOTE #6
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2022-09-01 16:37:00
Type: PCP Visit
Provider: Physician


Urgent Visit: 

A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of shortness of breath. He first had symptoms 3 weeks ago. He was treated with antibiotics and finish antibiotic course on August 16th. He reports continued nasal congestion, cough, production of sputum, shortness of breath, wheezing and subjective fevers/chills. He also reports some headaches. No nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. 

BP 122/07 | Pulse (!) 90 | Temp 97.8 °F (36.6 °C) | Resp 20 | SpO2 98% 

In no acute distress lungs are clear to auscultation Regular heart rate and rhythm. The abdomen is soft and non distended Assessment plan: A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of nasal congestion. I am going to obtain a respiratory viral panel, sputum culture and chest x ray. I am concerned about a pneumonia. I will start antibiotics and call him back with his lab results.

- The patient denies a history of myocardial infarction (MI) and family history of early cardiovascular disease.
- Initial troponin levels are markedly elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury.
- The ECG shows some left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).
- Cardiology consult recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission, indicating a high suspicion for acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
- The patient's symptoms and risk factors, along with the elevated troponin, support a highly suspicious history for cardiac involvement.

- Cardiology consultation recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission.
- The patient's symptoms and risk factors raise a high clinical suspicion for acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:47:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
3 hours of severe left sided chest pressure. Radiates to arm. Associated shortness of breath. Denies hx MI. Mildly
diaphoretic. Aspirin 324 per EMS.
HPI/PE:
Patient is a 68 y/o M w/ PMH HTN, HLD, CKD (not on dialysis) presenting for eval chest pain. Reports
chest pain started approximately 3 hours. Pressure-like, exertional Radiates to L shoulder. Does not
radiate to back. No ripping/tearing quality. Non-pleuritic. Associated with some SOB that worsens when
laying flat.
Denies prior hx ACS. Denies family hx early cardiovascular disease.
Does not see a cardiologist.
No hx DVT/PE. No hx recent surgery, immobilization, hormones. No smoking.
No fevers, chills, infectious symptoms.
MDM:
68M with risk factors and chest pain concerning for ACS. Initial troponin noted to be markedly elevated.
No history of prior troponin in chart. ECG no ST segment changes but some LVH. Cardiology consulted,
recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission. Low clinical suspicion for DVT/PE. No pneumonia/pnx
on CXR. Got aspirin pre-hospital. Heparin. Hold off on Brilinta per cardiology. Adm.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [06/29/23 1422]
BP: (!) 163/95
Pulse: (!) 115
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 22
Temp: 99.1 °F (37.3 °C)
Temp src: Oral
SpO2: 97%
BP (!) 163/95 | Pulse (!) 115 | Temp 99.1 °F (37.3 °C) (Oral) | Resp 22 | Wt (Wt Unknown)
Physical Exam
Procedures
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 06/29/23 1531
NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) (HC Code) (HC CODE) (HC Code)
ED Disposition
Admit

ENCOUNTER NOTE #2
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Registered Nurse


02:25 PM Pt w/ 3 hours chest pain, diaphoretic, uncomfortable appearing. NC O2 for comfort. Pt aox4,
vss. Steady gait. 8/10 chest pain. Radiates to shoulder. Aspirin by EMS. Tech getting EKG.
02:31 PM Medicated per MAR. MD at bedside, blood sent to lab.

The encounter diagnosis was Flank pain.

Given intermittent flank pain without clear laterality concern for possible renal vs MSK vs aortic

understyands risk. Doubt life-threatening process. Counseled on return precautions.

Discharge

Last Edited: 2023-06-14 16:17:00
Type: ED Visit 
Provider: Registered Nurse


2:20 PM Patient arrives to ED for eval of flank pain x 2 days. Some blood in urine. No fevers, chills, chest
pain, shortness of breath. In no acute distress. Needs to get home soon to take care of grandkids.
2:43 PM MD at bedside. Plan of care explained to patient, will need ultrasounds.

understanding and acceptance of discharge instructions. Discharged to home. All belongings returned to
patient.

Last Edited: 2022-09-01 16:37:00
Type: PCP Visit
Provider: Physician


Urgent Visit: 

A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of shortness of breath. He first had symptoms 3 weeks ago. He was treated with antibiotics and finish antibiotic course on August 16th. He reports continued nasal congestion, cough, production of sputum, shortness of breath, wheezing and subjective fevers/chills. He also reports some headaches. No nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. 

BP 122/07 | Pulse (!) 90 | Temp 97.8 °F (36.6 °C) | Resp 20 | SpO2 98% 

In no acute distress lungs are clear to auscultation Regular heart rate and rhythm. The abdomen is soft and non distended Assessment plan: A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of nasal congestion. I am going to obtain a respiratory viral panel, sputum culture and chest x ray. I am concerned about a pneumonia. I will start antibiotics and call him back with his lab results.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning: 
- The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLD), and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
- The chief complaint is severe left-sided chest pressure that radiates to the arm, associated with shortness of breath.
- The patient denies a history of myocardial infarction (MI) and family history of early cardiovascular disease.
- The initial troponin level is markedly elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.
- The ECG shows some left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).
- Cardiology consult recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission, indicating a high suspicion for acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
- The patient is admitted for further evaluation and management.

- The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLD), and chronic kidney disease (CKD).

- The patient denies a history of myocardial infarction (MI) but reports exertional chest pain that worsens when laying flat.
- The initial troponin level is markedly elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.
- The ECG shows some left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).
- Cardiology is consulted and recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission, indicating a high level of concern for acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
- The patient is admitted for further evaluation and management.

Overall, the patient's symptoms, risk factors, and diagnostic findings suggest a high suspicion for ACS, warranting further investigation and treatment.

because it was the closest safe place and he didn’t think he could get home.

for life threatening toxidrome. No indicated for emergent psychiatric evaluation at this time as he has no
SI/HI/AVH and is not grossly impaired. He has a reliable ride home with his wife so will give 1 time dose
of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.

No history of HTN per chart review, prior vitals wnl.

for life threatening toxidrome. No indicated for emergent psychiatric evaluation at this time as he has no
SI/HI/AVH and is not grossly impaired. He has a reliable ride home with his wife so will give 1 time dose
of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.
Noted to be tachycardic/hypertensive, suspect substance-related effect that should improve on its own.
No history of HTN per chart review, prior vitals wnl.

Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pt report 2 hr chest pain, used rowing machine before. R sided. No SOB. Hasn’t taken anything for pain. No hx MI.
HPI/PE:
Patient is a 50M w/ no sig PMH here w/ CP.
He reports pain started about 2 hours ago. At the time he was at the gym using a rowing machine
because his PCP has been getting him to lose weight. Reports losing 10 pounds over the last 2 months,
no longer overweight. Denies shortness of breath. Denies radiation of pain.
Describes pain as sharp, R sided, more shoulder than chest.
No history of prior shoulder injuries or rotator cuff injuries. Tender to palpation over the R anterior
rotator cuff.
No personal history of heart problems. No one in his family has had an MI.
MDM:
50M here w/ CP suspected to be mechanical in etiology. Considered ACS, however EKG non-ischemic
without any ST segment changes. Will get troponin and reassess. Doubt DVT/PE
Low suspicion for shoulder fracture or other emergent MSK process. May be related to rotator cuff
injury, however no emergent treatment would be indicated. Will try lidocaine patch and advice RICE for
now and have him follow up with PMD if his shoulder pain doesn’t get better.
Case discussed with attending physician.

The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)].

- The pain started after using a rowing machine, which could potentially be a trigger for cardiac symptoms.
- The pain is described as sharp and located on the right side, with more shoulder involvement than chest.
- The patient has no history of myocardial infarction (MI) but does have tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff.
- The EKG is non-ischemic without ST segment changes, but troponin levels are still pending.
- The patient's vital signs are within normal limits.
- The patient is discharged with a diagnosis of unspecified chest pain, but close follow-up with a primary care physician (PMD) is recommended if symptoms persist.

Overall, the patient's history raises concerns for potential cardiac involvement, and further evaluation and monitoring are warranted.

for life threatening toxidrome. No indicated for emergent psychiatric evaluation at this time as he has no
SI/HI/AVH and is not grossly impaired. He has a reliable ride home with his wife so will give 1 time dose
of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.

without any ST segment changes. Will get troponin and reassess. Doubt DVT/PE
Low suspicion for shoulder fracture or other emergent MSK process. May be related to rotator cuff
injury, however no emergent treatment would be indicated. Will try lidocaine patch and advice RICE for
now and have him follow up with PMD if his shoulder pain doesn’t get better.

of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.

SI/HI/AVH and is not grossly impaired. He has a reliable ride home with his wife so will give 1 time dose
of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.
Noted to be tachycardic/hypertensive, suspect substance-related effect that should improve on its own.

HPI/PE:
Patient is a 50M w/ no sig PMH here w/ CP.
He reports pain started about 2 hours ago. At the time he was at the gym using a rowing machine
because his PCP has been getting him to lose weight. Reports losing 10 pounds over the last 2 months,
no longer overweight. Denies shortness of breath. Denies radiation of pain.
Describes pain as sharp, R sided, more shoulder than chest.
No history of prior shoulder injuries or rotator cuff injuries. Tender to palpation over the R anterior
rotator cuff.
No personal history of heart problems. No one in his family has had an MI.
MDM:
50M here w/ CP suspected to be mechanical in etiology. Considered ACS, however EKG non-ischemic
without any ST segment changes. Will get troponin and reassess. Doubt DVT/PE
Low suspicion for shoulder fracture or other emergent MSK process. May be related to rotator cuff
injury, however no emergent treatment would be indicated. Will try lidocaine patch and advice RICE for
now and have him follow up with PMD if his shoulder pain doesn’t get better.
Case discussed with attending physician.

SI/HI/AVH and is not grossly impaired. He has a reliable ride home with his wife so will give 1 time dose
of benzo and have him talk to his PCP about behavioral health referrals. Strict return precautions for any
worsening or recurrent psychiatric symptoms.

HPI/PE:
Patient is a 50M w/ no sig PMH here w/ CP.
He reports pain started about 2 hours ago. At the time he was at the gym using a rowing machine
because his PCP has been getting him to lose weight. Reports losing 10 pounds over the last 2 months,
no longer overweight. Denies shortness of breath. Denies radiation of pain.
Describes pain as sharp, R sided, more shoulder than chest.
No history of prior shoulder injuries or rotator cuff injuries. Tender to palpation over the R anterior
rotator cuff.
No personal history of heart problems. No one in his family has had an MI.
MDM:
50M here w/ CP suspected to be mechanical in etiology. Considered ACS, however EKG non-ischemic
without any ST segment changes. Will get troponin and reassess. Doubt DVT/PE
Low suspicion for shoulder fracture or other emergent MSK process. May be related to rotator cuff
injury, however no emergent treatment would be indicated. Will try lidocaine patch and advice RICE for
now and have him follow up with PMD if his shoulder pain doesn’t get better.
Case discussed with attending physician.

Chief Complaint

EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.

pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.

The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning:
- The patient presents with chest pain that started after breakfast, is localized to the left side of the chest, and radiates into the neck. The pain worsens with deep respirations and is pleuritic. These characteristics are concerning for cardiac etiology.
- The patient has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease and diabetes mellitus, which are risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which raises concern for potential thrombotic events.
- The patient's ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which can be associated with cardiac ischemia.
- The patient's troponin levels are mildly elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which are commonly used in the management of cardiac chest pain.
- Cardiology has recommended expedited stress testing for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Overall, the patient's history, symptoms, and past medical conditions raise a high suspicion for cardiac involvement.

Consider the following risk factors: HTN, hypercholesterolemia, DM, obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), smoking (current, or smoking cessation ≤3 mo), positive family history (parent or sibling with CVD before age 65); atherosclerotic disease: prior MI, PCI/CABG, CVA/TIA, or peripheral arterial disease. 
 
 For the patient below, across all the combined encounter notes, how many risk factors are present? 
 [No known risk factors (0)] [1-2 risk factors (1)] [>= 3 risk factors or history of atherosclerotic disease (2)] [Not enough information to determine Risk Factor score]
 
 Please first explain your reasoning and then provide your final choice, listing one option between the answers above in brackets (e.g. [No known risk factors (0)] ).
 
#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [08/01/23 1209]
BP: 118/63
Pulse: (!) 103
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 25
Temp: 98.3 °F (36.8°C)
Temp src: Temporal
SpO2: 97%
BP 118/63| Pulse (!) 103 | Temp 98.3 °F (36.8°C) (Temporal) | Resp 25 | Wt 148.3 kg
Physical Exam
Constitutional
Appearance: Normal appearance. No acute distress.
HENT:
Head: Normocephalic and atraumatic
Eyes:
Conjunctiva/sclera: Conjunctivae normal. Sclera non-icteric.
Cardiovascular:
Rate and Rhythm: Tachycardic rate and regular rhythm.
Pulses: Decreased pulses (difficult to palpate pulses in radial, DP, PT).
Heart sounds: Normal heart sounds.
Pulmonary:
Effort: Pulmonary effort is increased.
Breath sounds: Normal breath sounds.
Abdominal:
General: Bowel sounds are normal.
Palpations: Abdomen is soft.
Tenderness: Abdomen is nontender. There is no left or right CVA tenderness.
Skin:
General: Skin is warm and dry.
Neurological:
General: No focal deficit present.
Procedures
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 08/01/23 15:53
Chest pain, unspecified type
ED Disposition
Observation


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #2
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:11:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Registered Nurse


12:24 PM 54F with several hours of left sided chest pain. Radiates to neck. +pleuritic. Reports several of
her family have had PEs in the past but doesn’t think she has had one. No cough, fever, SOB. No hx MI.
Received aspirin and EKG at triage. Labs/IV. Placed on monitor, side rails in place, call bell in reach.
01:03 PM Chest pain still persistent 5/10, MD aware, nitroglycerin administered per MAR.
01:25 PM Patient reports continued chest pain 4/10, MD notified no new orders at this time.
02:41 PM Chest pain is now resolved. No other new or worsening symptoms.
03:45 PM Per d/w MD patient will be admitted to chest pain center for stress test tomorrow. Handover
provided to CPC RN.
04:05 PM Patient transported to CPC further care deferred to CPC RN.


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #3
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-07-23 19:30:00
Type: ED Visit 
Provider: Registered Nurse


6:26 PM Pt arrives from radiology after getting L ankle XR to r/o fx after accidentally dropping knife on
foot. She was at work cutting onions when the accident happened. Registration at bedside providing
workman’s comp pamphlet. Tetanus UTD.
6:49 PM Laceration repair by MD at bedside.
7:16 PM Patient discharged after completion of lac repair. Pain controlled. Has a safe ride home. Denies
any additional concerns. All questions addressed by provider. Ambulatory to WR w/ steady gait.


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #4
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-07-23 19:17:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Laceration
Slicing onions and dropped cleaver on L foot. Bleeding controlled in field by EMS. No thinners. TDAP UTD.
HPI/PE:
Ms. is a 54F with PMH PAD presenting for a laceration.
was in the kitchen today chopping onions at work when she lost control of the knife and dropped in
onto her left foot. She was wearing closed-toes shoes however sustained a deep laceration over the
anterior L ankle. She controlled bleeding with a towel until EMS arrived and applied a pressure dressing.
She denies pulsatile bleeding.
Denies any other injuries.
Her last tetanus was 3 years ago.
The knife had not been used on any meat prior to the injury.
She doesn’t think she lost much blood at the scene.
She does report a history of LE PAD. She follows with Dr. (Burmingham Vascular Group) and report she
has had some “stents done” but doesn’t have any records.
MDM:
This is a 54 y/o F presenting to the ED for evaluation of a laceration. Wound was thoroughly irrigated
with saline and there was no evidence of joint involvement on thorough probing. An ankle x-ray was
obtained and did not demonstrate any underlying fracture. DP/PT are palpable, doubt vascular injury.
Intact neurologic status. Will repair and DC with PMD follow-up for suture removal. Strict return
precautions for signs of wound infection given. No indication for antibiotics given clean wound.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [07/23/23 1804]
BP: 121/75
Pulse: (!) 128
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: (!) 28
Temp: 98.1 °F (36.7°C)
Temp src: Temporal
SpO2: 100%
BP 121/75| Pulse (!) 128 | Temp 98.1 °F (36.7°C) (Temporal) | Resp (!) 28 | Wt 74.1 kg
Physical Exam
Constitutional
Appearance: Normal appearance.
Cardiovascular:
Rate and Rhythm: Normal rate and regular rhythm.
Pulses: Normal pulses.
Heart sounds: Normal heart sounds.
Pulmonary:
Effort: Pulmonary effort is normal.
Breath sounds: Normal breath sounds.
Extremity:
MSK: Tenderness is present. (Laceration over L ankle with no exposed bone/tendon/joint.)
Procedures
See separately dictated procedure note.
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 07/23/23 1912
Laceration
ED Disposition
Discharge

S: 54 yo presents for problem visit
Pt reporting that over the past month, she has had significant pain in her soles first thing in the morning.
She says that with her leg pain, it has been very difficult to walk much and she has been staying in bed or
on the couch more. She noticed that over the past month, when she first stands in the morning, her
bilateral soles “hurt like burning” and often she has to sit back down. She stats that “it feels like my feet
are on fire and tearing up”, very discouraged as her “legs hurt with walking and feet hurt with standing”.

Peripheral vascular disease

- Patient reassured, referred to PT

Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest

her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with

She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

• Laceration

Ms. is a 54F with PMH PAD presenting for a laceration.
was in the kitchen today chopping onions at work when she lost control of the knife and dropped in
onto her left foot. She was wearing closed-toes shoes however sustained a deep laceration over the
anterior L ankle. She controlled bleeding with a towel until EMS arrived and applied a pressure dressing.
She denies pulsatile bleeding.

Her last tetanus was 3 years ago.

has had some “stents done” but doesn’t have any records.

This is a 54 y/o F presenting to the ED for evaluation of a laceration. Wound was thoroughly irrigated
with saline and there was no evidence of joint involvement on thorough probing. An ankle x-ray was
obtained and did not demonstrate any underlying fracture. DP/PT are palpable, doubt vascular injury.
Intact neurologic status. Will repair and DC with PMD follow-up for suture removal. Strict return
precautions for signs of wound infection given. No indication for antibiotics given clean wound.

Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

- The patient presents with chest pain that started after breakfast, is localized to the left side of the chest, and radiates into the neck. The pain worsens with deep respirations and is pleuritic. These characteristics are concerning for cardiac etiology.
- The patient has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease and diabetes mellitus, which are risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which raises concern for thromboembolic disease.
- The patient denies OCP use, recent surgery, long-distance travel, or trauma, which makes other potential causes less likely.
- The patient's ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which can be associated with cardiac pathology.
- The patient's troponin level is mildly elevated, indicating potential cardiac damage.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which can be indicative of ischemic etiology.
- Cardiology has recommended expedited stress testing for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

- The patient presents with chest pain that started after breakfast, is localized to the left side of the chest, and radiates into the neck. The pain is pleuritic and worsens with deep respirations. These characteristics are consistent with cardiac chest pain.
- The patient has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II), and tobacco use disorder, which are all risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which raises concern for potential thrombotic events.
- The patient's ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which can be associated with cardiac ischemia.
- The patient's troponin levels are mildly elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which are commonly used to treat cardiac chest pain.
- The patient is being referred to a chest pain center for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Based on this information, the patient's history is highly suspicious for cardiac-related chest pain.

was in the kitchen today chopping onions at work when she lost control of the knife and dropped in
onto her left foot. She was wearing closed-toes shoes however sustained a deep laceration over the
anterior L ankle. She controlled bleeding with a towel until EMS arrived and applied a pressure dressing.
She denies pulsatile bleeding.

Her last tetanus was 3 years ago.
The knife had not been used on any meat prior to the injury.
She doesn’t think she lost much blood at the scene.
She does report a history of LE PAD. She follows with Dr. (Burmingham Vascular Group) and report she
has had some “stents done” but doesn’t have any records.
MDM:
This is a 54 y/o F presenting to the ED for evaluation of a laceration. Wound was thoroughly irrigated
with saline and there was no evidence of joint involvement on thorough probing. An ankle x-ray was
obtained and did not demonstrate any underlying fracture. DP/PT are palpable, doubt vascular injury.
Intact neurologic status. Will repair and DC with PMD follow-up for suture removal. Strict return
precautions for signs of wound infection given. No indication for antibiotics given clean wound.

 NOTE [#1] IN CURRENT ENCOUNTER

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.

pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited

- The patient's troponin levels are mildly elevated, indicating possible myocardial injury.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which are commonly used for cardiac chest pain.
- The patient is being referred to a chest pain center for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Reasoning: 
- The patient presents with chest pain that started after breakfast, is localized to the left side of the chest, and radiates into the neck. The pain is pleuritic and worsens with deep respirations. These characteristics are concerning for cardiac etiology.
- The patient has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II), and tobacco use disorder, which are risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient denies a known history of CAD but has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which raises suspicion for potential thrombotic events.
- The ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which can be associated with cardiac conditions.
- The troponin level is mildly elevated, indicating potential cardiac damage.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which are commonly used for cardiac-related chest pain.
- Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited stress testing, further supporting the suspicion of a cardiac etiology.

Therefore, the history is highly suspicious (2).

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),

Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),

pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was

Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

- The patient has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II), and tobacco use disorder, which are all risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which raises concern for potential thrombotic events.
- The patient denies known history of CAD, but there is no documentation of a stress test to rule out coronary artery disease.
- The patient's ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which is a concerning finding.
- Troponin levels are mildly elevated, indicating possible myocardial injury.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which may suggest an ischemic etiology.
- The patient is tachypneic on exam, which may indicate respiratory distress.
- The patient's chest radiography does not show evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
- The patient will be referred to a chest pain center for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

- The patient presents with chest pain that started after breakfast and is localized to the left side of the chest, radiating into the neck. The pain worsens with deep respirations and is described as sharp. These characteristics are concerning for cardiac origin.
- The patient has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism, which increases the suspicion for thromboembolic disease.
- The patient has a history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II), and tobacco use disorder, which are risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
- The patient's ECG shows a new left bundle branch block, which can be indicative of underlying cardiac pathology.
- The patient's troponin levels are mildly elevated, further raising concern for cardiac involvement.
- The patient's symptoms have resolved with aspirin and nitroglycerin, which can be consistent with ischemic etiologies.
- The patient is being referred to a chest pain center for further evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Based on these findings, the patient's history is highly suspicious for cardiac involvement.

is a 38 y/o woman with no significant PMH presenting to the ED for evaluation of chest pain.
She reports that her chest pain started while she was making breakfast about an hour ago and has been
continuous since then. Pressure-like. Describes like “someone sitting on my chest”. Associated nausea,
no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.

stress testing.

inversions in the anterior leads.

Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents

# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now

consideration of IV antibiotics

Chief Concern: right lower extremity wound
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED
Review of Systems
As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a past medical history of Anxiety (since childhood)
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
FAMILY HISTORY: family history includes heart disease in her mother
SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.
Medications:
• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.
• hydrOXYzine (VISTARIL) 100 mg
capsule
TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH FOUR TIMES DAILY AS
NEEDED FOR ITCHING OR anxiety
PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals:
BP: 120/62
Pulse: 76
Resp: 17
Temp: 98.9 °F (37.2 °C)
General: NAD
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.

she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.

presents to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. While she has a limited medical history without
significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal
ECG. Given these considerations, I have high suspicion for ACS as the etiology of her chest pain. Chest x-
ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

- The initial troponin was elevated and declining, indicating possible myocardial injury.
- The patient has been admitted for further cardiac workup.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits

Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness

ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

hist_gptResponse:
The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning: 
- The patient presents with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and neck, described as pressure-like, and has been continuous for about an hour. This is concerning for cardiac origin.
- The patient reports multiple episodes of similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency.
- The patient has a family history of heart attack and sudden death at relatively young ages.
- The patient has never seen a cardiologist and has no prior stress testing.
- The ECG performed by EMS shows T-wave inversions in the anterior leads, which is a concerning finding.
- The initial troponin level was elevated, indicating possible myocardial injury.
- The patient has been admitted for further cardiac workup.

Overall, the combination of symptoms, family history, abnormal ECG findings, and elevated troponin level raises a high suspicion for acute coronary syndrome (ACS) as the etiology of the chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED

As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
FAMILY HISTORY: family history includes heart disease in her mother
SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.
Medications:
• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.
• hydrOXYzine (VISTARIL) 100 mg
capsule

NEEDED FOR ITCHING OR anxiety

Vitals:

Pulse: 76
Resp: 17
Temp: 98.9 °F (37.2 °C)
General: NAD
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal

ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning: The patient presents with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and neck, described as pressure-like, and has had multiple episodes of similar pain over the last few days. The patient is being admitted for further cardiac workup.

Arrives by EMS, 8/10 chest pain radiating to left shoulder, neck. Pressure-like. No hx MI. Abnl EMS EKG. Aspirin PTA.
HPI/PE:
is a 38 y/o woman with no significant PMH presenting to the ED for evaluation of chest pain.
She reports that her chest pain started while she was making breakfast about an hour ago and has been
continuous since then. Pressure-like. Describes like “someone sitting on my chest”. Associated nausea,
no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.
Has been having some exertional dyspnea climbing stairs for the last few weeks.
She denies any other shortness of breath.
No fevers, chills, or other infectious symptoms.
She does not have a personal history of CAD however she reports her mother had a heart attack when
she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.
MDM:
presents to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. While she has a limited medical history without
significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal
ECG. Given these considerations, I have high suspicion for ACS as the etiology of her chest pain. Chest x-
ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

- no fevers at home

Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED

today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED

As per HPI

mg tablet

ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

hist_gptResponse:
The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning: 
- The patient's chief complaint is chest pain, which is a concerning symptom.
- The pain is described as pressure-like and radiates to the left shoulder and neck, which are common symptoms of cardiac chest pain.
- The patient reports multiple episodes of similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency.
- The patient has a family history of heart attack and sudden death, which increases the suspicion for cardiovascular disease.
- The EMS EKG showed T-wave inversions in the anterior leads, which is abnormal and suggestive of ischemia.
- The patient has been experiencing exertional dyspnea, which can be a symptom of cardiac disease.
- The initial troponin was elevated and declining, indicating cardiac damage.
- The patient's physical exam is unremarkable, but it does not rule out a cardiac etiology for the chest pain.
- The patient is being admitted for further cardiac workup, indicating a high suspicion for ACS (acute coronary syndrome).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED
Review of Systems
As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a past medical history of Anxiety (since childhood)
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
FAMILY HISTORY: family history includes heart disease in her mother
SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.
Medications:
• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.
• hydrOXYzine (VISTARIL) 100 mg
capsule
TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH FOUR TIMES DAILY AS
NEEDED FOR ITCHING OR anxiety
PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals:
BP: 120/62
Pulse: 76
Resp: 17
Temp: 98.9 °F (37.2 °C)
General: NAD
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

is a 38 y/o woman with no significant PMH presenting to the ED for evaluation of chest pain.
She reports that her chest pain started while she was making breakfast about an hour ago and has been
continuous since then. Pressure-like. Describes like “someone sitting on my chest”. Associated nausea,
no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.
Has been having some exertional dyspnea climbing stairs for the last few weeks.
She denies any other shortness of breath.
No fevers, chills, or other infectious symptoms.
She does not have a personal history of CAD however she reports her mother had a heart attack when
she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.
MDM:
presents to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. While she has a limited medical history without
significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal
ECG. Given these considerations, I have high suspicion for ACS as the etiology of her chest pain. Chest x-
ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.

she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.

stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.

significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal

hist_gptResponse:
The patient's history is highly suspicious [Highly suspicious (2)]. 

Reasoning:
- The patient is a 38-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presenting with chest pain.
- The pain is described as pressure-like, radiating to the left shoulder and neck, and has been continuous for about an hour.
- The patient reports multiple episodes of similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency.
- She has been experiencing exertional dyspnea for the last few weeks.
- There is a family history of heart attack in the mother at age 42 and sudden death in the father at age 50.
- The EMS EKG showed T-wave inversions in the anterior leads, which is a concerning finding.
- The initial troponin was elevated and declining.
- The patient's symptoms and history raise a high suspicion for acute coronary syndrome (ACS) as the cause of her chest pain.
ekgQ:

consideration of IV antibiotics

# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED
Review of Systems
As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None

Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.

• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet

every 6 (six) hours as needed.

capsule

Pulse: 76
Resp: 17

General: NAD
